   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 67 year old male h/o HTN, systolic HF, and COPD who presented
   to an OSH with SOB and LE edema developed chest pain with ST-T wave
   changes on ECG prompting cardiac cath that showed severe 3 vessel
   disease. Transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] for further management.
   # Multivessel CAD:   Evaluated by CT [**Doctor First Name **] overnight. Plan at this time
   is to proceed with CABG this am.
          - TTE and carotid duplex this am
   -cont nitro gtt for pain control
keep SBP greater than 100 to maintain
   coronary perfusion
   -cont ASA
   -cont BB
   -NPO for procedure
   -f/u any pre-op CT [**Doctor First Name 91**] recs
   .
   #. Pump: Bedside ECHO by fellow showed EF 30-35% with trace aortic
   regurg and 1+ mitral regurg. Remains euvolemic.
   -lasix 80 mg [**Hospital1 **]
   -cont Metoprolol 75 mg TID
   -cont Lisinopril 10 mg daily
   .
   # Rhythm: Remains in atrial fibrillation. Patient previously on
   coumadin which was held on admission to OSH. Currenly HR in the low
   100
   -Will give 5mg IV lopressor bolus to get HR<100
   -Cont Metoprolol 75mg TID
   -Cont Digoxin
   .
   # COPD: Remains diffusely wheezy.
   -cont supplemental O2 to keep sats>94%
   -cont IV solumedrol
   -hold alb to prevent tachycardia
   -cont atrovent PRN
   .
   # Hct Drop: Likely represents GI bleed though source unclear. Was guiac
   pos at OSH.
   -Holding anticoagulation other than ASA at this time
   -Transfuse 2 units tonight given Hct 28 up from 27 this am despite 1
   unit PRBC at OSH today
   -cont IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   -guiac all stools
   -endoscopy would likely not be possible given severity of cardiac
   disease
   -active T and S
   -check Hct post transfusion and serially thereafter
   .
   # HTN: BP well controlled at this time. Trying to keep SBPs > 100 to
   maintain coronary artery perfusion
   -          cont Metoprolol 75 mg TID
   -          cont Lisinopril 10 mg daily
   .
   # Hyperlipdemia: cont statin
   .
   # Tobacco Abuse: Deferrred nicotine patch at this time

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of hypertension, systolic heart failure, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath and leg edema, and subsequently developed chest pain with ST-T wave changes on electrocardiogram (ECG). This prompted a cardiac catheterization that revealed severe three-vessel coronary artery disease (CAD). The patient was transferred to another hospital for further management.

On admission, the patient was started on nitroglycerin for chest pain control, beta-blockers for blood pressure control, and aspirin for antiplatelet therapy. He was also placed on a low-sodium diet and instructed to restrict fluid intake. The patient's vital signs were stable with a heart rate in the low 100s, blood pressure around 130/70 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation above 95%.

A bedside echocardiogram showed moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with an ejection fraction (EF) of 30-35%. The right ventricular cavity was dilated with borderline normal function. There was trace aortic regurgitation and mild mitral regurgitation. The patient's blood glucose levels were elevated at 216 mg/dL, but his troponin-T levels were within normal range.

The patient's laboratory results showed a slightly elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin

   .
   # Tobacco Abuse: Deferrred nicotine patch at this time
   .
   # ETOH Abuse: Patient reports last drink 7 days ago. No evidence of
   withdrawl at this time.
   - Cont to monitor. Implement CIWA scale if e/o withdrawl symptoms.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for procedure
   Glycemic Control:  QACHS fingersticks and humalog SS

   DVT: no anticoagulation given bleeding risk
   Stress ulcer: RISK
   Communication: With patient
   Code status: FULL
 (discussed with patient)
   Disposition: CCU for now
Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of hypertension, systolic heart failure, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath and lower extremity edema. He then developed chest pain with ST-T wave changes on the electrocardiogram (ECG), prompting cardiac catheterization that revealed severe three-vessel disease. The patient was transferred to this hospital for further management.

24-hour events:
- The patient experienced chest pain at 21:11 that improved with nitroglycerin.
- He was given a total of 15 mg IV lopressor for atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.
- A bedside echocardiogram showed moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with an ejection fraction (EF) of 30-35%. There was relative sparing of the inferior wall with hypokinesis of the remaining myocardial segments. The right ventricular cavity was dilated with borderline normal free wall function. The aortic valve was not well seen, but there was no aortic valve stenosis. Trace aortic regurgitation and mild (1+) mitral regurgitation were observed. There was no pericardial effusion.
- The patient will undergo an echocardiogram and carotid duplex in the morning.
- He received 2 units of packed red blood cells for a hematocrit (Hct) level of 28.
- No additional episodes of chest pain occurred overnight.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Multivessel CAD: The patient is evaluated by Cardiology overnight. The plan is to proceed with coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery in the morning.
   - Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and carotid duplex in the morning
   - Chest X-ray (CXR) in the morning
   - Continue nitroglycerin for pain control
   - Keep systolic blood pressure (SBP) greater than 100 to maintain coronary perfusion
   - Continue aspirin (ASA) and beta-blocker (BB) therapy
   - NPO (nothing by mouth) for procedure
   - Follow-up with preoperative Cardiology recommendations

2. Pump: The bedside echocardiogram last night showed an EF of 30-35% with trace aortic regurgitation and 1+ mitral regurgitation. The patient remains euvolemic on examination.
   - Hold lasix this morning given the patient is going to surgery
   - Continue metoprolol 75 mg three times daily (TID)
   - Continue lisinopril 10 mg daily

3. Rhythm: The patient remains in atrial fibrillation with a controlled heart rate in the 80s.
   - Give 5 mg IV lopressor bolus to get HR < 100
   - Continue met

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU for chest pain and multivessel coronary artery disease (CAD). The patient experienced an episode of chest pain at 2111, which improved with nitroglycerin. He was given a total of 15 mg IV lopressor for atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR). The bedside echo showed moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with an ejection fraction of 30-35%. There was relative sparing of the inferior wall with hypokinesis of the remaining myocardial segments. The right ventricular cavity was dilated with borderline normal free wall function. The aortic valve was not well seen, but there was no aortic valve stenosis. Trace aortic regurgitation was observed. The mitral valve leaflets were moderately thickened, and mild (1+) mitral regurgitation was seen, although the severity of mitral regurgitation may be underestimated due to acoustic shadowing. There was no pericardial effusion. The patient received 2 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) for a hematocrit level of 28. The patient did not have any additional episodes of chest pain overnight.

Medical Complications:
1. Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient received lopressor for this condition.
2. Moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction: The patient's ejection fraction is

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension, systolic heart failure, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath and lower extremity edema, followed by chest pain and ST-T wave changes on electrocardiogram (ECG). A cardiac catheterization revealed severe three-vessel coronary artery disease (CAD). He was transferred to this hospital for further management.

The patient's current condition includes multivessel CAD, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib/RVR), systolic heart failure, COPD, and a recent drop in hemoglobin concentration (Hct) likely due to gastrointestinal bleeding. He is currently receiving nitroglycerin for chest pain control, beta-blockers for blood pressure control and rate control in AFib, and diuretics for fluid management.

The plan is to proceed with coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery in the morning. Preoperative assessments include a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and carotid duplex, as well as a chest X-ray. In the meantime, the patient's medications will be continued, including aspirin, beta-blockers, and statins. He will be kept nil per os (NPO) for the procedure. 

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications: The patient has severe multivessel CAD and syst

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of hypertension, systolic heart failure, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath and lower extremity edema, and subsequently developed chest pain with ST-T wave changes on electrocardiogram (ECG), leading to cardiac catheterization that revealed severe three-vessel disease. 

The patient was transferred to another hospital for further management, where he underwent a bedside echocardiogram showing moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with an ejection fraction of 30-35%. There is relative sparing of the inferior wall with hypokinesis of the remaining myocardial segments. The right ventricular cavity is dilated with borderline normal free wall function. The aortic valve is not well seen, but there is no aortic valve stenosis. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen, and the mitral valve leaflets are moderately thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is present, with the severity potentially underestimated due to acoustic shadowing. There is no pericardial effusion.

The patient's current medications include nitroglycerin, metoprolol, furosemide (Lasix), and lisinopril. He is also on supplemental oxygen to maintain oxygen saturation above 94%. The plan is to proceed with coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery in

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of hypertension, systolic heart failure, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath and lower extremity edema, which were followed by chest pain and ST-T wave changes on the ECG. Subsequently, he underwent cardiac catheterization that revealed severe three-vessel disease. He was transferred to another hospital for further management.

The patient has been diagnosed with multivessel coronary artery disease (CAD) and is planned for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery. Prior to the surgery, a bedside echocardiogram showed moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with an ejection fraction of 30-35%, trace aortic regurgitation, and mild mitral regurgitation.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 102 beats per minute, blood pressure of 134/73 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95% on nasal cannula. His physical examination reveals diffuse wheezing consistent with COPD and 1+ lower extremity pitting edema.

Laboratory findings include a white blood cell count of 9.6 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin concentration of 28.3 g/dL, platelet count of 243 x 10
